channel.title: Gizmodo
channel.feedburner:browserFriendly: This is an XML content feed. It is intended to be viewed in a newsreader or syndicated to another site.

item.title: Watch This Chain of Beads Dash Across the Room All On Its Own
item.description:
When you put chains and physics together, you get results that are borderline magic, and this experiment from MIT proves it. No, this chain doesn't seem to float in mid-air, but it does walk across the room.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Eric Limer

item.title: How to Get Your Luggage Back When the Airline Loses It
item.description:
Next to an unfortunate incident involving the aircraft itself, lost luggage is easily the second biggest fear of air travellers. And while most of us will thankfully never have to deal with such a headache, there's no guaranteeing your bags will be there waiting for you after your next flight.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Andrew Liszewski

item.title: A Paper Shopping Bag That Transforms Into a Hanger Back Home
item.description:
If you get lucky, the clothing store where you bought that new sweater or shirt might toss in the plastic hanger it was on free of charge. Otherwise, you'll have to scrounge one up yourself—at least until this wonderful redesign of the shopping back becomes a reality. With a few folds the Hangbag transforms into its own hanger, strong enough to support everything short of a lead-lined suit.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Andrew Liszewski

item.title: You're Using the Semicolon All Wrong
item.description:
Wait, you use the semicolon for sentence construction? Are you for real? Surely, nobody really knows how to use that thing properly anymore. It's probably for the best that it's only ever used to form winky emoticons these days. [Doghouse Diaries]

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Jamie Condliffe

item.title: Tech Workers, Walking, Loneliness: What's Ruining Our Cities This Week
item.description:
Those damn dot-commers are still mucking up San Fran, parents are passing along their dangerous pedestrian ways to the next generation, a giant suitcase is an eyesore in Red Square, and—sigh—we're all so lonely. These things and more are What's Ruining Our Cities.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Alissa Walker

item.title: The First In-Flight Movies Had a Live Orchestra
item.description:
As crude as they may seem when compared to the home theater setups we enjoy in our living rooms, the in-flight entertainment options available on most flights have come a long way. Although, it's hard not to feel a tinge of sadness that movies accompanied by live orchestras never caught on. Now that was flying in style.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Andrew Liszewski

item.title: This Rolls-Royce Tanker Is a School Bus for Salmon
item.description:
Fish tends to spoil fast, even when kept on ice. So to ensure that farm-raised salmon remain at peak of their freshness (read: still swimming) for whole trip to back to shore for processing, Rolls-Royce is building the world's largest mobile aquarium/meat wagon.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Andrew Tarantola

item.title: Gawker ​The Best Walmart Thanksgiving Day Fight Videos | io9 Nope.
item.description:
Gawker ​The Best Walmart Thanksgiving Day Fight Videos | io9 Nope. Scientists did not just find an 'alcoholism gene' | Jalopnik The Best Automotive Black Friday Deals | Lifehacker Everything You Need to Know About Black Friday and Cyber Monday | Defamer Evan Rachel Wood Tells The MPAA "Women Don't Just Have To Be Fucked"

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Jessica Smith on Jessica, shared by Geoff Manaugh to Gizmodo

item.title: The Best Black Friday App Deals
item.description:
Black Friday's not just for real-world goods; it's also arguably the biggest day of the year for sales on great apps. We've listed a ton of the best deals below, and we'll add more as we see them. If you know of any we missed, let us know in the comments!

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Shep McAllister, Commerce Team

item.title: This Massive Steel Structure Will Entomb Chernobyl's Reactor 4
item.description:
When an unexpected power surge sparked the world's worst nuclear accident in Chernobyl, nearly a quarter of a million construction workers risked their lives to build an ad hoc "sarcophagus" of concrete around the stricken reactor. It was a stop-gap measure—and now, almost 3o years later, one of the biggest engineering projects in history is underway to protect it.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Campbell-Dollaghan

item.title: For Retailers, Today Really Is the Shittiest Day of the Year
item.description:
You've heard of Black Friday, the darkest day for American capitalism; Cyber Monday, where everyone gets out their latent shopping aggression online; now there's even Grey Thursday, as retailers open on Thanksgiving Eve to get an edge on the competition. But, friends, have you heard of Brown Friday?

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Alissa Walker

item.title: 10 Simple Party Tricks To Impress Your Turkey-Stuffed Friends
item.description:
Thanksgiving dinner might be over for another year, but you've got a fridge full of leftovers that says friends and family will be stopping by for another meal today. And if you're worried your famous pumpkin pie isn't going to be enough to impress them, Richard Wiseman is back with another collection of super simple party stunts that are sure to leave people amazed and bewildered—even if they're not drunk.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Andrew Liszewski

item.title: ​Sex 'n Spas: The Future (And Not So Future) of In-Flight Entertainment
item.description:
Careening through the air 30,000 feet above the ground can be a brutal experience. To help us cope, airlines have evolved some pretty sophisticated on-demand entertainment in the form of games, movies, internet, and the occasional backrub. Here's a look at some of the ambitious ideas that got us there, the failures along the way, and concepts we might see in the future.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Mario Aguilar

item.title: This Stealth Camera Captures Images in Almost Complete Darkness
item.description:
If you thought low-light photography was coming on in leaps and bounds, you ain't seen nothin' yet. This new camera, developed by researchers at MIT, can capture ultra-sharp images of objects even when they're illuminated by just a handful of photons.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Jamie Condliffe

item.title: These Colorful Floor Tiles Were Made From Snail Poop
item.description:
Stepping on snails is nasty—feeling the distinctive crack-and-squelch beneath your foot is all sorts of ugh-ack-yuck-ew. Dutch artist, designer, and scientific researcher Lieske Schreuder found a way to make the experience less visceral but arguably more disgusting, by creating tiles composed of terrestrial mollusc turds.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: jordan kushins

item.title: Evolution Doesn't Look Like You Think It Does
item.description:
There's an iconic scientific image which depicts evolution, and it suggests that we went from monkey to man in six easy steps. The only problem is, that's kinda bull.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Jamie Condliffe

item.title: A New and Aggressive Strain of HIV Is Spreading Across West Africa
item.description:
A newly discovered strain of HIV is spreading across West Africa. What's worse is that it's particularly aggressive—and causes significantly faster progression to AIDS than other strains.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Jamie Condliffe

item.title: For 20 Years the Nuclear Launch Code at US Minuteman Silos Was 00000000
item.description:
Today I found out that during the height of the Cold War, the US military put such an emphasis on a rapid response to an attack on American soil, that to minimize any foreseeable delay in launching a nuclear missile, for nearly two decades they intentionally set the launch codes at every silo in the US to 8 zeroes.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Karl Smallwood - TodayIFoundOut.com

item.title: This Is Why 4D Printing Is Cool
item.description:
The U.S. Army Research Office has just thrown some money the way of 4D printing—but what, exactly, is all the fuss about? This beautiful video goes a long way to showing us why the technology is so exciting.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Jamie Condliffe

item.title: Apple's Black Friday Deals: Lots of Gift Cards
item.description:
If you've been eagerly awaiting Apple's Black Friday offers, then they're finally here! You will, however, have to make do with gift cards. Here's a rundown of what you can get your hands on.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Jamie Condliffe

item.title: Comet Ison May Still Be Alive (Updated)
item.description:
Yesterday, comet Ison flew close to the Sun, and many sources reported its death. Now, though, some scientists are claiming that it, or at least some part of it, may have survived its journey.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Jamie Condliffe

You can now buy Pebble's smartwatch from Amazon, for the princely sum of $150.

item.title: The Weirdest Thing on the Internet Tonight: Studies on Hysteria (NSFW)
item.description:
A one-eyed man might be king in the land of the blind, but heaven help the guy wearing pants in this nudist colony.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Andrew Tarantola

item.title: Build This Ray Gun Synth That Generates Wonderfully Retro PewPew Sounds
item.description:
Usually, if you're building your own synthesizer, you have aspirations of composing the next great techno track. But this kit—available from the Maker SHED for just $20—lets you build a wonderful toy ray gun that generates electronic "pewpew" sound effects. And, instead of just cycling through various sounds like you would with a cheap toy, you can use the gun's three adjustable knobs to tweak the wub, bwoop, and bip bip sounds however you like.

Read more...
item.dc:creator: Andrew Liszewski
